section.heading: Unlawful distribution of a prohibited animal product.

para.text: Beginning one year after October 1, 2020, a person commits the offense of unlawful distribution of a prohibited animal product if that person knowingly imports, sells, offers for sale, purchases, barters, trades, or possesses with intent to sell a prohibited animal product.
Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a person does not commit the offense of unlawful distribution of a prohibited animal product if the person:
Bequeaths the prohibited animal product to the legal beneficiary of an estate or trust upon the death of the owner;
Gifts or donates the prohibited animal product without remuneration;
Is a government employee or agent conducting law enforcement activities pursuant to federal, state, or local law;

Is an educational or scientific institution that imports, sells, offers for sale, purchases, barters, trades, or possesses with intent to sell a prohibited animal product for educational or scientific purposes;
Is engaging in an activity that is expressly authorized by federal law or a permit issued pursuant to federal law;
Imports, sells, offers for sale, purchases, barters, trades, or possesses with intent to sell a prohibited animal product that is part of an antique that:
Is composed of not more than 20% of a prohibited animal product by volume; and
The person can, through documentation, establish provenance and demonstrate that the antique is at least 100 years old; or
Imports, sells, offers for sale, purchases, barters, trades, or possesses with intent to sell a prohibited animal product that is part of a musical instrument that:
Is composed of less than 20% of a prohibited animal product by volume; and
The person can establish provenance and demonstrate that the musical instrument was manufactured before 1976.
The act of obtaining an appraisal of a prohibited animal product alone shall not constitute possession with intent to sell or offer for sale.
